cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
where did the british army launch a successful invasion in 1776
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
In 1776, the British Army was engaged in the American Revolutionary War, which involved several military campaigns against the American colonies. One of the most significant events of that year was the British invasion of New York City. The British aimed to capture New York as it was a strategic location for controlling the colonies and facilitating further military operations. The British forces, under General William Howe, successfully landed on Staten Island in late June 1776 and then moved to capture Brooklyn, leading to the Battle of Long Island in August. This campaign ultimately resulted in the British taking control of New York City.

Answer:
The British Army launched a successful invasion in New York City in 1776.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
where did the british army launch a successful invasion in 1776
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
["The Planned French Invasion of Britain, 1708, also known as the 'Entreprise d’Écosse,' took place during the War of the Spanish Succession. The French planned to land 5,000-6,000 soldiers in North-East Scotland to support a rising by local Jacobites that would restore James Francis Edward Stuart to the throne of Great Britain. Leaving Dunkirk in March 1708, the fleet reached Scotland but was unable to disembark the troops and returned home, narrowly escaping a pursuing British naval force. \n", 'In 1402, Scottish nobles launched a coordinated invasion of Northern England. In the initial foray, some 12,000 Scottish troops crossed into Cumberland and looted areas near Carlisle. On 22 June at Nisbet, Berwickshire, the forfeited George de Dunbar, 10th Earl of March successfully led 200 English soldiers, mainly drawn from the garrison at Berwick-upon-Tweed, against 400 Scots returning from a raid on Northumberland.\n', "The English invasion of Scotland of August 1400 was the first military campaign undertaken by Henry IV of England after deposing the previous king, his cousin Richard II. Henry IV urgently wanted to defend the Anglo-Scottish border, and to overcome his predecessor's legacy of failed military campaigns.\n", 'After failing to persuade the Icelandic government to join the Allies, the UK invaded on the morning of 10 May 1940. The initial force of 746 Royal Marines commanded by Colonel Robert Sturges disembarked at the capital Reykjavík. Meeting no resistance, the troops moved quickly to disable communication networks, secure strategic locations, and arrest German citizens. Requisitioning local transport, the troops moved to Hvalfjörður, Kaldaðarnes, Sandskeið, and Akranes to secure potential landing areas against the possibility of a German counterattack.\n', 'In 1756 Britain and France had formally gone to war after initial clashes in North America. The French began the war successfully by capturing Menorca a British island in the Mediterranean. After this Britain had gained the initiative at sea and had begun a series of naval incursions on the French coast, such as the Raid on Rochefort (1757) and the Raid on Cherbourg (1758), pioneered by the Southern Secretary William Pitt. While the practical success of these was limited, they caused serious alarm throughout France and forced the French government to detach large numbers of troops to guard coastal areas against further British raids. Pitt suspended the campaign in late 1758 following an unsuccessful landing at Saint Cast, while remaining open to the idea of further operations against the vulnerable French coast.\n', 'The English invasion of Scotland of 1296 was a military campaign undertaken by Edward I of England in retaliation to the Scottish treaty with France and the renouncing of fealty of John, King of Scotland and Scottish raids into Northern England.\n', "The third, and most successful, invasion took place in Cornwall in September 1497. In May and June 1497, there had been a revolt against Henry VII in Cornwall. This had been suppressed following the rebels' defeat at Blackheath. However, there was still sufficient dissatisfaction that when Warbeck arrived with a small force, he was accepted by many locals as Richard IV and soon raised a force of up to 8,000 rebels. With this army, he besieged Exeter. The fighting, over two days, was bloody, with the rebels making assaults on North and East gates. One or both gates were penetrated but the attackers were driven out after fierce street fighting. 300–400 rebels are alleged to have been killed during the attack. With the failure of the attack, the rebel army withdrew to Taunton. By this time, however, a royal army was approaching and the morale of the rebels began to crack. Warbeck fled on 21 September but was captured at Beaulieu Abbey in Hampshire.\n", 'The English invasion of Scotland of 1298 was a military campaign undertaken by Edward I of England in retaliation to a Scottish uprising in 1297, the defeat of an English army at the Battle of Stirling Bridge and Scottish raids into Northern England.\n', 'The French victory at the battle of Beachy Head two years earlier, in June 1690, had opened up the possibility of destroying a significant part of the Anglo-Dutch fleet and landing an invading army. King Louis XIV and his naval minister, Louis Phélypeaux, planned to land an army in England and restore James II to the throne. They planned to launch the invasion in April 1692, which was earlier than the separate English and Dutch fleets were expected to put to sea and combine. Much of the invasion force was to be made up of the Irish Royal Army which had gone into exile in the Flight of the Wild Geese after the siege of Limerick in 1691.\n', "The French invasion emerged in 1545, when Admiral Claude d'Annebault crossed the Channel and arrived off the Solent with 200 ships on 19 July. Henry's fleet made a brief sortie, before retreating safely behind the protective fortifications. Annebault landed a force near Newhaven, during which Camber Castle may have fired on the French fleet, and on 23 July they landed four detachments on the Isle of Wight, including a party that took the site of Sandown Castle, which was still under construction. The French expedition moved further on along the coast on 25 July, bringing an end to the immediate invasion threat. Meanwhile, on 22 July the French had carried out a raid at Seaford, and Camber Castle may have seen action against the French fleet. A peace treaty was agreed in June 1546, bringing an end to the war. By the time that Henry died the following year, in total the huge sum of £376,000 had been spent on the Device projects.\n"]

To address the question regarding where the British Army launched a successful invasion in 1776, we need to analyze the provided passages for relevant historical context and information that may be unfamiliar or not directly related to the question. 

### Extracted Content and Analysis

While these invasions are not directly related to the British Army's actions in 1776, they provide context on Britain's military history and its longstanding conflicts with Scotland. Understanding these historical invasions can help frame the military strategies and territorial ambitions of Britain during the 18th century.

2. **Military Campaigns and Strategies**:
   - The passages mention military campaigns and invasions, such as the French invasion attempts and the British naval incursions against France. This context is crucial for understanding the geopolitical landscape of the time, including the ongoing conflicts between Britain and France, which influenced British military decisions in the American Revolutionary War.

3. **The American Revolutionary War**:
   - Although none of the passages directly mention the American Revolutionary War or the specific events of 1776, the context of military invasions and campaigns can help the model infer that the British Army was engaged in significant military operations during this period. The year 1776 is particularly notable for the Declaration of Independence in the American colonies, which led to increased military actions by the British.

4. **The Role of Naval Power**:
   - The passages highlight the importance of naval power in historical invasions, such as the British naval incursions against the French coast. This aspect is relevant to understanding the British Army's capabilities and strategies in 1776, as naval superiority was crucial for transporting troops and supplies to the American colonies.

5. **Geopolitical Implications**:
   - The references to various invasions and military campaigns illustrate the broader geopolitical implications of military actions during this era. The British Army's invasion efforts in 1776 were part of a larger struggle for control and influence, both in Europe and in the colonies.

### Conclusion

The extracted content provides a rich historical background that can enhance the understanding of the British Army's military actions in 1776. While the passages do not directly answer the question, they offer insights into the military strategies, historical conflicts, and geopolitical context that shaped Britain's approach during the American Revolutionary War. This understanding is essential for comprehending the significance of the British Army's operations in 1776 and the challenges they faced in their attempts to maintain control over the American colonies. 

To answer the original question specifically, the British Army launched a successful invasion in 1776 at **New York**, where they defeated American forces and took control of the city, marking a significant moment in the American Revolutionary War.

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To address the question of where the British Army launched a successful invasion in 1776, we must consider the historical context of the American Revolutionary War and the specific military actions taken by the British during that year.

1. **Context of the American Revolutionary War**:
   - The American Revolutionary War (1775-1783) was a conflict between Great Britain and thirteen of its North American colonies, which declared independence as the United States of America. By 1776, the war was escalating, and the British sought to regain control over the rebellious colonies.

2. **Strategic Importance of New York**:
   - New York City was a strategically vital location for both military and logistical reasons. It served as a major port and was centrally located, making it an ideal base for British operations in the colonies. Capturing New York would allow the British to control the flow of goods and reinforcements and to divide the colonies geographically.

3. **British Military Campaigns in 1776**:
   - In June 1776, British forces under General William Howe landed on Staten Island. This marked the beginning of a campaign aimed at capturing New York City. The British forces then moved to Brooklyn, where they engaged American troops in the Battle of Long Island in August 1776. This battle was a decisive victory for the British, leading to their control of Brooklyn and subsequently New York City.

4. **Naval Support and Logistics**:
   - The British Navy played a crucial role in the success of the invasion. The Royal Navy's dominance at sea allowed for the safe transport of troops and supplies, which was essential for sustaining military operations in the colonies. The ability to control the waters around New York facilitated the British Army's movements and reinforced their strategic advantage.

5. **Outcome and Significance**:
   - The successful invasion of New York City in 1776 not only provided the British with a critical foothold in the colonies but also had significant implications for the morale of both British and American forces. The capture of New York was a major setback for the Continental Army and demonstrated the British Army's military capabilities.

### Conclusion

Based on the enhanced reasoning process, we can conclude that the British Army launched a successful invasion in 1776 at **New York City**. This invasion was marked by the landing of British forces on Staten Island, the subsequent Battle of Long Island, and the eventual capture of the city, which played a pivotal role in the British strategy during the American Revolutionary War.

### Answer:
The British Army launched a successful invasion in New York City in 1776.

Meanwhile, on 22 July the French had carried out a raid at Seaford, and Camber Castle may have seen action against the French fleet. A peace treaty was agreed in June 1546, bringing an end to the war. By the time that Henry died the following year, in total the huge sum of £376,000 had been spent on the Device projects.
"]

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract key elements from the provided passages that illustrate the relationships between events, motivations, and outcomes. Here’s a consolidation of relevant information along with an analysis of how this can improve the model's capabilities:

### Extracted Content:

1. **Historical Context and Motivations**:
   - The **Planned French Invasion of Britain (1708)** was motivated by the desire to support a Jacobite rising, indicating how political aspirations can drive military actions.
   - The **English invasions of Scotland (1296, 1298, 1400, 1402)** were responses to Scottish uprisings and treaties, showcasing how invasions can be retaliatory measures against perceived threats or betrayals.

2. **Military Campaigns and Outcomes**:
   - The **French invasion of England (1692)** was planned to restore James II, highlighting how invasions can be tied to dynastic claims and political legitimacy.
   - The **failed French invasion of England (1545)** demonstrates the impact of naval power and fortifications on the success of military campaigns, emphasizing the importance of strategic planning and readiness.

3. **Local Reactions and Morale**:
   - The **Cornish rebellion (1497)** illustrates how local dissatisfaction can lead to the acceptance of foreign invaders, showing the interplay between local sentiment and military success.
   - The **withdrawal of Warbeck's forces** due to the approach of a royal army highlights how morale and external pressures can influence the outcomes of military engagements.

4. **Strategic Decisions**:
   - The **British naval incursions during the Seven Years' War** (1756) forced France to allocate resources defensively, indicating how military actions can shift the strategic landscape and compel adversaries to react.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Causality**:
   - By analyzing the motivations behind invasions and the subsequent military actions, the model can learn to identify causal relationships, such as how political instability can lead to military interventions. This understanding is crucial for reasoning about historical events and their implications.

2. **Event Sequencing**:
   - The passages provide examples of how one event leads to another (e.g., failed invasions leading to changes in military strategy). This can help the model improve its ability to sequence events logically and understand the flow of history.

3. **Interpreting Outcomes**:
   - The outcomes of military campaigns (success or failure) are often influenced by a combination of factors, including local support, strategic decisions, and external pressures. The model can enhance its inferential capabilities by learning to weigh these factors when predicting outcomes of similar scenarios.

4. **Complex Interactions**:
   - The interactions between different actors (e.g., local populations, foreign powers, and military leaders) illustrate the complexity of historical events. The model can improve its reasoning by recognizing that outcomes are rarely the result of a single cause but rather a web of interconnected factors.

5. **Strategic Implications**:
   - Understanding the strategic implications of military actions (e.g., resource allocation, morale) can help the model make more nuanced inferences about future scenarios based on historical precedents.

In summary, the extracted content provides a rich tapestry of historical events that can enhance the model's ability to reason causally and infer logically. By integrating these insights, the model can better understand the complexities of historical narratives and apply this understanding to new contexts.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.
question:
where did the british army launch a successful invasion in 1776
answer:
Reasoning process:
In 1776, the British Army was engaged in the American Revolutionary War, which involved several military campaigns against the American colonies. One of the most significant events of that year was the British invasion of New York City. The British aimed to capture New York as it was a strategic location for controlling the colonies and facilitating further military operations. The British forces, under General William Howe, successfully landed on Staten Island in late June 1776 and then moved to capture Brooklyn, leading to the Battle of Long Island in August. This campaign ultimately resulted in the British taking control of New York City.

Answer:
The British Army launched a successful invasion in New York City in 1776.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

In 1776, the British Army was deeply involved in the American Revolutionary War, which was characterized by a series of military campaigns aimed at quelling the rebellion of the American colonies against British rule. A pivotal moment in this conflict was the British invasion of New York City, which was strategically significant for several reasons.

1. **Historical Context and Motivations**:
   - The British aimed to capture New York City to establish a stronghold in the colonies, facilitating control over trade routes and military operations. This aligns with historical patterns where invasions are often motivated by the desire to secure strategic locations, as seen in previous invasions like the **Planned French Invasion of Britain (1708)**, which aimed to support a political cause.

2. **Military Campaigns and Outcomes**:
   - Under the command of General William Howe, British forces successfully landed on Staten Island in late June 1776. This initial landing was part of a broader strategy to capture New York, similar to how earlier military campaigns were planned with specific objectives in mind, such as the **French invasion of England (1692)**, which was aimed at restoring a monarch.

3. **Event Sequencing**:
   - Following the landing, the British moved to capture Brooklyn, leading to the **Battle of Long Island** in August 1776. This sequence of events illustrates how initial military actions can lead to subsequent engagements, a concept that can enhance the model's ability to understand causality in historical narratives.

4. **Local Reactions and Morale**:
   - The local population's response to the British invasion played a crucial role in the campaign's success. Understanding how local sentiments can influence military outcomes is vital, as seen in the **Cornish rebellion (1497)**, where local dissatisfaction led to significant military engagements.

5. **Strategic Decisions**:
   - The British decision to focus on New York City was influenced by its geographical advantages and the need to control key areas for further military operations. This reflects the strategic considerations that often dictate military campaigns, similar to how earlier invasions were shaped by the need to respond to threats or opportunities.

By synthesizing these elements, we can see that the British invasion of New York City in 1776 was not just a standalone event but part of a larger strategic framework influenced by historical precedents, local dynamics, and military objectives.

### Answer:
The British Army launched a successful invasion in New York City in 1776, capturing it after landing on Staten Island and defeating American forces at the Battle of Long Island. This invasion was part of a broader strategy to control the colonies during the American Revolutionary War.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
where did the british army launch a successful invasion in 1776
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
["The Planned French Invasion of Britain, 1708, also known as the 'Entreprise d’Écosse,' took place during the War of the Spanish Succession. The French planned to land 5,000-6,000 soldiers in North-East Scotland to support a rising by local Jacobites that would restore James Francis Edward Stuart to the throne of Great Britain. Leaving Dunkirk in March 1708, the fleet reached Scotland but was unable to disembark the troops and returned home, narrowly escaping a pursuing British naval force. \n", 'In 1402, Scottish nobles launched a coordinated invasion of Northern England. In the initial foray, some 12,000 Scottish troops crossed into Cumberland and looted areas near Carlisle. On 22 June at Nisbet, Berwickshire, the forfeited George de Dunbar, 10th Earl of March successfully led 200 English soldiers, mainly drawn from the garrison at Berwick-upon-Tweed, against 400 Scots returning from a raid on Northumberland.\n', "The English invasion of Scotland of August 1400 was the first military campaign undertaken by Henry IV of England after deposing the previous king, his cousin Richard II. Henry IV urgently wanted to defend the Anglo-Scottish border, and to overcome his predecessor's legacy of failed military campaigns.\n", 'After failing to persuade the Icelandic government to join the Allies, the UK invaded on the morning of 10 May 1940. The initial force of 746 Royal Marines commanded by Colonel Robert Sturges disembarked at the capital Reykjavík. Meeting no resistance, the troops moved quickly to disable communication networks, secure strategic locations, and arrest German citizens. Requisitioning local transport, the troops moved to Hvalfjörður, Kaldaðarnes, Sandskeið, and Akranes to secure potential landing areas against the possibility of a German counterattack.\n', 'In 1756 Britain and France had formally gone to war after initial clashes in North America. The French began the war successfully by capturing Menorca a British island in the Mediterranean. After this Britain had gained the initiative at sea and had begun a series of naval incursions on the French coast, such as the Raid on Rochefort (1757) and the Raid on Cherbourg (1758), pioneered by the Southern Secretary William Pitt. While the practical success of these was limited, they caused serious alarm throughout France and forced the French government to detach large numbers of troops to guard coastal areas against further British raids. Pitt suspended the campaign in late 1758 following an unsuccessful landing at Saint Cast, while remaining open to the idea of further operations against the vulnerable French coast.\n', 'The English invasion of Scotland of 1296 was a military campaign undertaken by Edward I of England in retaliation to the Scottish treaty with France and the renouncing of fealty of John, King of Scotland and Scottish raids into Northern England.\n', "The third, and most successful, invasion took place in Cornwall in September 1497. In May and June 1497, there had been a revolt against Henry VII in Cornwall. This had been suppressed following the rebels' defeat at Blackheath. However, there was still sufficient dissatisfaction that when Warbeck arrived with a small force, he was accepted by many locals as Richard IV and soon raised a force of up to 8,000 rebels. With this army, he besieged Exeter. The fighting, over two days, was bloody, with the rebels making assaults on North and East gates. One or both gates were penetrated but the attackers were driven out after fierce street fighting. 300–400 rebels are alleged to have been killed during the attack. With the failure of the attack, the rebel army withdrew to Taunton. By this time, however, a royal army was approaching and the morale of the rebels began to crack. Warbeck fled on 21 September but was captured at Beaulieu Abbey in Hampshire.\n", 'The English invasion of Scotland of 1298 was a military campaign undertaken by Edward I of England in retaliation to a Scottish uprising in 1297, the defeat of an English army at the Battle of Stirling Bridge and Scottish raids into Northern England.\n', 'The French victory at the battle of Beachy Head two years earlier, in June 1690, had opened up the possibility of destroying a significant part of the Anglo-Dutch fleet and landing an invading army. King Louis XIV and his naval minister, Louis Phélypeaux, planned to land an army in England and restore James II to the throne. They planned to launch the invasion in April 1692, which was earlier than the separate English and Dutch fleets were expected to put to sea and combine. Much of the invasion force was to be made up of the Irish Royal Army which had gone into exile in the Flight of the Wild Geese after the siege of Limerick in 1691.\n', "The French invasion emerged in 1545, when Admiral Claude d'Annebault crossed the Channel and arrived off the Solent with 200 ships on 19 July. Henry's fleet made a brief sortie, before retreating safely behind the protective fortifications. Annebault landed a force near Newhaven, during which Camber Castle may have fired on the French fleet, and on 23 July they landed four detachments on the Isle of Wight, including a party that took the site of Sandown Castle, which was still under construction. The French expedition moved further on along the coast on 25 July, bringing an end to the immediate invasion threat. Meanwhile, on 22 July the French had carried out a raid at Seaford, and Camber Castle may have seen action against the French fleet. A peace treaty was agreed in June 1546, bringing an end to the war. By the time that Henry died the following year, in total the huge sum of £376,000 had been spent on the Device projects.\n"]

question_info.question: where did the british army launch a successful invasion in 1776
passages:
The Planned French Invasion of Britain, 1708, also known as the 'Entreprise d’Écosse,' took place during the War of the Spanish Succession. The French planned to land 5,000-6,000 soldiers in North-East Scotland to support a rising by local Jacobites that would restore James Francis Edward Stuart to the throne of Great Britain. Leaving Dunkirk in March 1708, the fleet reached Scotland but was unable to disembark the troops and returned home, narrowly escaping a pursuing British naval force. 
In 1402, Scottish nobles launched a coordinated invasion of Northern England. In the initial foray, some 12,000 Scottish troops crossed into Cumberland and looted areas near Carlisle. On 22 June at Nisbet, Berwickshire, the forfeited George de Dunbar, 10th Earl of March successfully led 200 English soldiers, mainly drawn from the garrison at Berwick-upon-Tweed, against 400 Scots returning from a raid on Northumberland.
The English invasion of Scotland of August 1400 was the first military campaign undertaken by Henry IV of England after deposing the previous king, his cousin Richard II. Henry IV urgently wanted to defend the Anglo-Scottish border, and to overcome his predecessor's legacy of failed military campaigns.
After failing to persuade the Icelandic government to join the Allies, the UK invaded on the morning of 10 May 1940. The initial force of 746 Royal Marines commanded by Colonel Robert Sturges disembarked at the capital Reykjavík. Meeting no resistance, the troops moved quickly to disable communication networks, secure strategic locations, and arrest German citizens. Requisitioning local transport, the troops moved to Hvalfjörður, Kaldaðarnes, Sandskeið, and Akranes to secure potential landing areas against the possibility of a German counterattack.
In 1756 Britain and France had formally gone to war after initial clashes in North America. The French began the war successfully by capturing Menorca a British island in the Mediterranean. After this Britain had gained the initiative at sea and had begun a series of naval incursions on the French coast, such as the Raid on Rochefort (1757) and the Raid on Cherbourg (1758), pioneered by the Southern Secretary William Pitt. While the practical success of these was limited, they caused serious alarm throughout France and forced the French government to detach large numbers of troops to guard coastal areas against further British raids. Pitt suspended the campaign in late 1758 following an unsuccessful landing at Saint Cast, while remaining open to the idea of further operations against the vulnerable French coast.
The English invasion of Scotland of 1296 was a military campaign undertaken by Edward I of England in retaliation to the Scottish treaty with France and the renouncing of fealty of John, King of Scotland and Scottish raids into Northern England.
The third, and most successful, invasion took place in Cornwall in September 1497. In May and June 1497, there had been a revolt against Henry VII in Cornwall. This had been suppressed following the rebels' defeat at Blackheath. However, there was still sufficient dissatisfaction that when Warbeck arrived with a small force, he was accepted by many locals as Richard IV and soon raised a force of up to 8,000 rebels. With this army, he besieged Exeter. The fighting, over two days, was bloody, with the rebels making assaults on North and East gates. One or both gates were penetrated but the attackers were driven out after fierce street fighting. 300–400 rebels are alleged to have been killed during the attack. With the failure of the attack, the rebel army withdrew to Taunton. By this time, however, a royal army was approaching and the morale of the rebels began to crack. Warbeck fled on 21 September but was captured at Beaulieu Abbey in Hampshire.
The English invasion of Scotland of 1298 was a military campaign undertaken by Edward I of England in retaliation to a Scottish uprising in 1297, the defeat of an English army at the Battle of Stirling Bridge and Scottish raids into Northern England.
The French victory at the battle of Beachy Head two years earlier, in June 1690, had opened up the possibility of destroying a significant part of the Anglo-Dutch fleet and landing an invading army. King Louis XIV and his naval minister, Louis Phélypeaux, planned to land an army in England and restore James II to the throne. They planned to launch the invasion in April 1692, which was earlier than the separate English and Dutch fleets were expected to put to sea and combine. Much of the invasion force was to be made up of the Irish Royal Army which had gone into exile in the Flight of the Wild Geese after the siege of Limerick in 1691.
The French invasion emerged in 1545, when Admiral Claude d'Annebault crossed the Channel and arrived off the Solent with 200 ships on 19 July. Henry's fleet made a brief sortie, before retreating safely behind the protective fortifications. Annebault landed a force near Newhaven, during which Camber Castle may have fired on the French fleet, and on 23 July they landed four detachments on the Isle of Wight, including a party that took the site of Sandown Castle, which was still under construction. The French expedition moved further on along the coast on 25 July, bringing an end to the immediate invasion threat. Meanwhile, on 22 July the French had carried out a raid at Seaford, and Camber Castle may have seen action against the French fleet. A peace treaty was agreed in June 1546, bringing an end to the war. By the time that Henry died the following year, in total the huge sum of £376,000 had been spent on the Device projects.
